The rights of the patron against the lreedman’s estate were not only interesting to the ireeborn Roman in his possible character of a patron, but also in respect oi the manumission of children: lor an emancipating parent (parens manumissor) had the same claims against the estate left by the emancipated child as the manumitter of a slave had against the estate left by the freedman, i.e. a claim originally to a moiety and subsequently to a third oi the succession, either contra-tabular or ab intestato. He, however, could not bring actio Fabiana or Calvisiana to defeat dolose alienatione made in the lifetime of the emancipated child.
